description:
Gamsiella multidivaricata is a species of fungus belonging to the phylum Basidiomycota. It is a member of the order Agaricales, which includes many species of mushrooms and toadstools.

This fungus is characterized by its small, delicate fruiting bodies that emerge from the soil. The cap of the mushroom is typically white or pale in color and can range from 1 to 5 centimeters in diameter. The gills on the underside of the cap are closely spaced and run down the stem of the mushroom.

Gamsiella multidivaricata is known to form symbiotic relationships with the roots of certain plants, particularly those found in forested environments. This type of relationship, known as mycorrhizal, allows the fungus to obtain carbohydrates from the plant while providing the plant with increased access to water and nutrients from the soil.

The specific epithet "multidivaricata" refers to the branching and spreading nature of the fungus's mycelium, the underground network of filamentous structures that make up the main body of the organism.

Overall, Gamsiella multidivaricata is a small but ecologically important fungal species that plays a role in the cycling of nutrients and the maintenance of healthy forest ecosystems.
